references: FL protocols are designed to handle multiple devices collecting data and a central server coordinating the global learning objective across the network

.
Here the network refers specifically to the WAN among the devices and the cloud. The objective can be formulated as:
is the number of training samples in device
is total number of training samples in all devices and
is the loss function of device
, the aggregation is performed on cloud with the

across WAN.
However, a critical fact is ignored that most devices are distributed across different LANs.
Those devices in the same LAN can adopt P2P communication mechanism to aggregate models, which is much faster than the cloud aggregation across WAN.
Intuitively, the objective of our proposed

framework is to accelerate the WAN-driven FL protocol while ensuring model accuracy.
Our
introduces a LAN domain aggregation mechanism to achieve our goal, which can be formulated as:
is the number of total training samples in each LAN
is the loss function of LAN
denotes the number of training samples on device
denotes the number of devices in LAN
is the loss function of device
are respectively calculated on cloud (across WAN) and on aggregating device in each LAN

S3.T2.caption: Table 2. A comparison of WAN, LAN, and datacenters in consideration of their bandwidth capacity and optimal local epoch in distributed learning.
references:
To some extent, LanFLâ€™s LAN domain is similar to a distributed system in datacenter, where many machines are inter-connected through switches.
As summarized in TableÂ 2, regarding the network bandwidth capacity, however, LAN is somewhere between the WAN and datacenter.
It indicates a new spectrum of parameter tuning different from WAN-driven FL (typically very large Eğ¸E) and datacenter (typically as small as one batch per aggregation).

Datasets and models used in our experiments are summarized in TableÂ 3.
We test LanFL on 2 datasets: FEMNISTÂ (cohen2017emnist, ), CelebAÂ (liu2015deep, ). We re-use the scripts of LEAFÂ (leaf, ) to split each dataset into Non-IID setting and assign them to many devices.
For each dataset, we group the devices into different LAN domains (20 for each by default).
We apply LanFL on 2 models:
For CelebA, we use a CNN model with 4 CONV, 2 FC, and 84Ã—\times84 input size.
For FEMNIST, we use a CNN model with 2 CONV, 2 FC, and 28Ã—\times28 input size.

We first present the overall results of LanFL compared with WAN-FL.
TableÂ 4 summarizes the key metrics when model converges and FigureÂ 4 illustrates the convergence process.
For WAN-FL, we vary the local epoch number (Eğ¸E) for its key role in tuning FL performance (Â§Â§\S3.3).
For each device round in LAN-FL, LanFL selects 5 LAN domains (Nâ€‹Lsğ‘subscriptğ¿ğ‘ NL_{s}), and each domain involves 10 devices for training (Nâ€‹Csğ‘subscriptğ¶ğ‘ NC_{s}).
The WAN and LAN domain bandwidths are set to 2Mbps and 20Mbps, respectively.
Noting that this LAN bandwidth is the final network throughput after being shared across devices instead of the AP bandwidth capacity.
We will further evaluate LanFL with more settings in following subsections.

LanFL can significantly reduce WAN traffic and monetary cost.
Figure 4 shows that the number of cloud round Râ€‹Wğ‘…ğ‘ŠRW required by LanFL to converge is much fewer than baseline (87% on FEMNIST, 47% on CelebA), which brings in tremendous WAN traffic savings.
Table 4 also shows that the WAN traffic and monetary cost of LanFL is much less than baseline:
On FEMNIST, LanFL reduces 99 % WAN traffic and 97% monetary cost to the baseline;
On CelebA, LanFL reduces 95% WAN traffic and 79% monetary cost to the baseline.
The saved cost comes from both the reduced clock time to rent hardware resources and the reduced network traffic according to Eq. 9.
